larsejaas.com

Creating UI using React, TypeScript and/or whatever gets the job done.

Let's connect!

record.text:
üíÖ Using CSS Modules in your projects.  
CSS Modules are often underrated. Looking for an alternative to Tailwind CSS? They‚Äôre one of the cleanest ways to keep styles scoped to your components and avoid global CSS conflicts.

Let‚Äôs go through some practical tips. üßµ  
#DeveloperTips #CSSModules

actor.description:
Just a passionate dev, learning from this community daily. 

‚ú® Sharing the entire journey - bugs, breakthroughs, and banter. üöÄ

record.text:
‚úÖ Preprocessors?  
CSS Modules are often paired with Sass, but native CSS now supports nested selectors in all modern browsers, making Sass less essential.

If you previously relied on Sass mixins for reusable styles, you can often achieve the same with reusable classes using `composes`.

images.alt:
CSS showing:
.closeButton {  composes: button from '@components/buttons/button.module.css';   color: red; }

record.text:
üîÑ Re-using classes with `composes`  
You can ‚Äúspread‚Äù one class into another using `composes`.

Works a bit like Sass mixins but stays inside the CSS Modules ecosystem.

images.alt:
CSS showing:
.closeButton {  composes: button from '@components/buttons/button.module.css';   color: red; }

record.text:
üé¨ Importing animations

CSS Modules let you import from other `.module.css` files ‚Äî even keyframes!

The import syntax allows for renaming the keyframe animations - or use them as-is.

Now you can use the animation as if it were local.

ü™Ñ Cascade Layers Tip
Wrap all component styles in the `components` cascade layer.

Anything outside cascade layers has higher specificity.  

This makes it easier to override component styles from the outside when needed.

üõ°Ô∏è Type Safety
If you want full type safety in TypeScript, you can generate `.d.ts` files for your CSS Modules.

A package like typed-css-modules github.com/Quramy/typed... can do this automatically for all modules.  
Now classnames will be typed, avoiding typos and giving you editor autocompletion.

üåç Global styling
Most of the time, you‚Äôll want to keep styles local, but sometimes it‚Äôs useful to reference global classes, IDs, or states.

You can combine local and global selectors with the global keyword.

Here, `.someLocalClass` remains local, but its style adapts to a global state.
CSS Modules are simple but super powerful if you lean into these tricks. üöÄ

üí° TypeScript tip: Want autocomplete for common values BUT still allow any string? Here's a clever trick most devs don't know about!

String literal union types like `"apple" | "banana"` give great IDE autocomplete, but what if you need flexibility too? ü§î

#WebDev #TypeScript  #DeveloperTips

images.alt:
TypeScript code showing: 

type Fruit = "apple" | "banana" | string;

TypeScript widens this to just `string`

No more autocomplete! üò¢

record.text:
‚ùå The problem: Adding `string` to your union kills autocomplete

This happens because TypeScript widens to the most general type.

images.alt:
TypeScript code showing: 

type Fruit = "apple" | "banana" | string;

TypeScript widens this to just `string`

No more autocomplete! üò¢

record.text:
‚úÖ The solution: Use intersection with {}!

This magical syntax gives you BOTH:

Autocomplete for "apple" and "banana"
Ability to pass any string value

How does it work? ü™Ñ

üîç Why string & {} works:

- string & {} is still assignable from any string

- But it's a different type than plain string
- So TypeScript doesn't widen the union!
- Your IDE keeps the literal suggestions ‚ú®

The intersection doesn't change runtime behavior at all.

üöÄ Use cases:

- CSS properties with common values + custom
- API endpoints with known routes + dynamic
- Theme colors with presets + hex codes
- Any enum-like type that needs escape hatches

Try it in your next TypeScript project! Your future self (and teammates) will thank you.

üîß Dev tip: You can make your webpages XML sitemap human-readable by adding a sitemap.xsl file! Instead of showing raw XML, visitors get a clean nice-looking page.
Check out this example:
larsejaas.com/sitemap-0.xml
Much better than staring at angle brackets, right? üòÑ
#WebDev #SEO #DeveloperTips
